content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as SEC. 30B. Private Land Conservation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act provides a tax credit of 10% for eligible farmers and ranchers for qualified conservation contributions. The maximum credit for any taxable year is $360,000. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to $360,000 for any taxable year, with a special rule for joint returns where the credit is allocated equally. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to $360,000 for any taxable year, with a special rule for joint returns where the credit is allocated equally between spouses. Additionally, there is an aggregation rule for members of the same controlled group of corporations or persons under common control. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to $360,000 for any taxable year, with an aggregation rule for members of the same controlled group of corporations or persons under common control. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall not exceed the excess of the regular tax reduced by the sum of the credits allowable under subpart A. The tax credit limit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act for any taxable year is $360,000. The credit allowed for a taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by the sum of the credits allowable under subpart A. An eligible farmer or rancher, for this purpose, is an individual whose gross income from farming is 60 percent or more of their total gross income for the year. The term 'eligible farmer or rancher' refers to an individual or C corporation whose gross income from farming is 60 percent or more of their total gross income for the taxable year. For a C corporation, additional criteria include the gross income from farming being the majority of the corporation's income, non-publicly traded stock, and a certain asset value. The section applies to taxpayers who elect its application for the taxable year, with the election being irrevocable. No deduction is allowed under section 170 for qualified conservation. Excess credit can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. Sec. 30B. Private land conservation. The amendments apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Increase in charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. Section 170(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include qualified farmers and ranchers as individuals for conservation contributions. This change aligns with the definition in section 30B(d). Additionally, section 170(b)(2) is amended to specify eligible farmers and ranchers as defined. The amendment to Section 170(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code excludes eligible farmers or ranchers from certain provisions related to conservation contributions. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. Expansion of estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easement. Amendment to section 2031(c)(8) of the Internal Revenue Code removes clause (i) and redesignates clauses (ii) and (iii). Effective for estates of decedents dying after enactment of the Act.
